div.head: Introduction
div.p: This document is meant as an exemplar and test .docx file for a docx2tei profile of the TEI Stylesheets. Its other function is as the source for a .dotx Word template than can serve for authoring new or editing existing Word files (primarily books) with the intention of converting them to TEI with, say, OxGarage.
This profile imports Stylesheets/profiles/default/docx/from.xsl and extends it a bit, but also requires a certain style while editing the Word document to be converted:

list.item: The more is done with Word styles, the better; and formatting and esp. layout is not well preserved.

The division before the first heading, with Title, Subtitle, Author and Date goes to the element tei:front, with the rest of the text in this division ignored; the first heading and the rest is tei:body.
Styles starting with “tei:” are substituted by their TEI element, c.f. Section “TEI elements”;

Some styles also have shorthand notation, e.g. a series of Bibliography-style paragraphs go into tei:listBilb/tei:bibl+ and tei:orgName goes to tei:name[@type=”org”], and some styles get extra processing,

Problems with phrase level elements containing initial or final space, which should probably go outside the element (e.g. “foo<term> bar </term>baz” → “foo <term>bar</term> baz”)
Word leaves many dead <anchor>s , these could be cleaned up
Embedded XSL could also be converted and inserted into TEI?

Facsimiles! Ideally maybe submit zip with docx+pdf, and make pointers into pdf if poss., or split into page images and link.

div.head: Standard character level styles
div.p: Things like bold, italic, underline, and strikethrough and red are stored as hi/@rend, as well as italic bold underline strikethrough, but the exact details, such as the colour of underline and more fancy text effects are not preserved. Information on fonts is not preserved.
We can also have dates in paragraphs, e.g. 1984-04-04.

div.head: TEI element styles
div.p: These styles start with “tei:” and the string following is - typically - the name of the TEI element. It some cases, to make them easier to use, the styles are mapped to more complicated structures; to see which and how it is easiest to compare this file with the derived TEI. The styles presented here use lots of eye watering effects, which need some work.

div.head: Paragraph level styles and elements
div.p: These styles are paragraph level, i.e. they mark complete paragraphs.
First, a quote, which is always outside paragraphs:
The doer alone learneth.
A citation with bibliographic item:
div.cit: A spectre is haunting Europe; the spectre of Communism. The Communist Manifesto (1848), by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
div.p: Next, a bit of poetry, using tei:lg:
div.lg: There once was a man from Nantucket
Who kept all his cash in a bucket.
And as for the bucket, Nantucket.
div.p: We can also have individual lines of poetry, without line group:
div.l: There once was a man from Nantucket
Who kept all his cash in a bucket.
div.p: A drama speech, with the convention that the first paragraph goes to speaker and the rest are lines:
div.sp: Though this be madness, yet there is method in ’t.
Will you walk out of the air, my lord?

div.head:
Character level styles / phrase level elements
It turns out to be problematic to have phrase-level styles in notes, c.f. AUMÜLLER, Jutta: Assimilation: Kontroversen um ein migrationspolitisches Konzept. Bielefeld: Transcript Verlag, 2009.
div.p: These styles appear inside paragraphs:
Name text Organisation text Person text Place text.
Bibl text Foreign text “Quoted” text.
Damage text (reason for) Gap text Supplied text Surplus text Unclear text.

div.head: Janus elements
div.p: The following pairs of elements get, if they are adjacent, a parent element: tei:subst for tei:del + tei:add and tei:choice for the others:
Add text Delete Add text Delete.
Abbreviation text Abbreviation Expansion text Expansion.
text Orig text Orig Regularised text Regularised text.
text Sic text Sic Corr text Corr text.
